newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine High Court to settle phone rate dispute.
newsitem.headline: Argentine High Court to settle phone rate dispute.

text.p: Argentina's Supreme Court will settle a controversial telephone rate change introduced by presidential decree January 30, Prosecutor General Angel Aguero Iturbe said Wednesday.
Two lower courts had issued rulings previously on the telephone tariff issue, and today's statement from the Supreme Court cleared up where the heated topic will be finally determined.
The decree increased the cost of local calls and boosted telephone rentals by up to 41 percent, but cut rates for long-distance and international calls.
Argentina's two telephone companies, Telefonica and Telecom, had waged a long lobbying campaign for the changes which they said would make charges fairer for provincial businesses.
They also hoped it would prepare them for the opening of the Argentine phone market to competition, possible at the end of 1997 but more likely in the year 2000.
But consumer groups and opposition parties decried the tariff hikes and argued Telecom and Telefonica would make windfall profits, which the companies emphatically denied.
Two weeks ago, the government had appealed a Federal Capital judge's decision to suspend the rate hikes on local telephone calls.
Meanwhile, a judge in the central province of Cordoba ruled in favor of the changes and said his verdict was applicable to the entire country and could not be appealed.

"There is a state of uncertainty because the decree has been questioned in contradictory rulings by national courts," Aguero Iturbe said in a written statement Wednesday. "(Going to the Supreme Court) is the best way to end this judicial uncertainty."
